Headline: Marketplace Growth | Cross-Border Trade | Food @Walmart Canada | Ivey MBA
Comment:
Loved this post, Rishabh, really resonated with me.

When I started out, I was tempted to chase every channel too. But I chose to focus all my energy on just one platform on one time and committed to doing one product line at a time, even though I was managing multiple categories and brands behind the scenes.

That focus helped me go deep: understanding what drives real growth, building strong customer feedback loops, and figuring out what works operationally. Once I had that clarity, I gradually expanded into other marketplaces, Shopify, and international markets, but always with the mindset of staying lean and deliberate.

That strategy helped me consistently build strong category positions not by being everywhere, but by being intentional and ready to scale when the foundation was solid.

Appreciate you putting this out there, more D2C founders need to hear this.

#D2C #FocusMatters #AmazonGrowth #eCommerceStrategy #BuildSmart

Headline: Founder & CEO @ Giggr Technologies | Design Learning | Building a Digitally Intelligent Platform As Service | Transforming Global Capability
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala The real problem is not having a design in place. Giggr - The Future of Work recommend that whether one is a startup or grownup , every enterprise needs a design playbook. Here is an overview: https://bit.ly/designplaybookbygiggrtech

When technology becomes centric to business, a new approach is needed. It is not enough to use technology for distribution and reach. It is necessary to connect the In-bound, Out-bound and Operational logistics of the business with technology. This is where the Product - Market - Fit (PMF) fails for almost everyone with Digital Transformations becoming a dud for the grown up enterprises and the PMF failing for startups. 

Happy to dialog further with anyone that cares to DM me on this.

Scaling purely on Quick commerce.

70% market share in the guilt-free ice cream category on quick-commerce. 

Just because of focusing on a single channel.

Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala a different view. We are working investors with a D2C but with a different approach:

1. Achieved ‚Çπ3 lacs / week in sales in the neighbourhood of the four founders. Time taken 45 days.

2. Stretched the geographies by a bit to achieve ‚Çπ10 lacs / week. Time taken 23 days.

3. Expanded to connect the four localities over 9 PIN codes to achieve ‚Çπ100 lacs / week. Time taken 87 days.

4. Covered Bengaluru to achieve ‚Çπ350 lacs / week. Time taken 195 days.

Today their free cashflow model is at ‚Çπ5.80 Cr a month. Getting into Hyderabad (2025) and Chennai (2026). They are in the business of assorted batters with monthly sales of just under ‚Çπ12 Crores.

Headline: Bringing authentic and wholesome food to you
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala As rightly said 'channel market fit' is the key.
But to find the channel market fit, one will need to try multiple channels. Is there any other better way to find channel market fit?

As a bootstarpped new startup, we are going through the same dilemma.

My thoughts are as below

1. If one has a unique product proposition, one can try a D2C website first.

2. If one has a large product line up, D2C website may be more suited first

3. If it's a 'me too' product, Amazon/ flipkart or other market place may be more suited as a first  channel.

4. For 'me too' product, offline markets and B2B can also be explored.

Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala  It‚Äôs true. I‚Äôve seen this first hand, with many brands. 

Mostly these kind of thoughts will be with early stage brands or companies entering D2C for the very first time. They think expanding their brand presence to multiple platforms/marketplaces increases the sales & brand visibility. 

Though it is acceptable to a certain level, I‚Äôm afraid of the costs & investment it is demanding. Like purchasing of inventory management tool/software, additional staffing.

Sometimes poor customer experience is inevitable and this will make a customer with bad experience in one platform to repel from that brand on other platforms. 

One big hurdles for brands with multiple market place presence is the inventory tracking and reconciling.

Headline: Co-founder at QPe | Simplifying E-commerce | "Best Tech Startup of the Year 2023" by MSME India
Comment:
Totally agree with you, Rishabh Mariwala! If D2C brands focus on building and growing their own website, it will lead to a more profitable and sustainable journey.  

Relying too much on marketplaces comes with major downsides: inventory mismanagement, loss of customer trust, and high commission fees that eat into profits. Marketplaces are ultimately strengthening their own brand by selling vendor products with zero risk, while brands bear the entire burden of returns and refunds.  

At QPe, we are empowering D2C brands to take full control of their business, generate millions in revenue, and build a direct relationship with their customers, all without paying any commission.
